pageData.text: is the process by which rock, soil, and other earth materials move down a slope because of gravitational forces. Slope movements are one of the costliest geologic hazards in the United States; on average they cause between 25 to 50 deaths per year and contribute between 1 billion and 2 billion dollars in economic losses. In this lab we will identify the leading factors that contribute to mass wasting and learn how to categorize the different types based on water saturation and slope movement.

text: Define what a <button class='glossary-text'>landslide</button> is and analyze the roles that slope, gravity, and the <button class='glossary-text'>angle of repose</button> play when identifying a landslide.
Describe how water saturation levels and slope movement are used to categorize landslide types.
Employ Google Earth to examine the after effects of historic landslides and identify high-risk landslide areas.

pageData.text: The Grand Canyon may be one of the most amazing examples of how <button class='glossary-text'>mass wasting</button> can shape the landscape. The National Park Service suggested that when you think of the Grand Canyon, you should think of DUDE (Deposition, Uplift, Down cutting, and Erosion)<sup>1</sup>. It is estimated that about two billion years ago, igneous and metamorphic rocks formed the inner gorge. The Colorado Plateau was formed through the action of plate tectonics between 70 and 30 million years ago when the whole region was uplifted. About 6 million years ago, the Colorado River began carving out the canyon and further erosion from tributary streams and rain continues to widen the Grand Canyon today.

Today, the Colorado River and Grand Canyon provide many different recreational opportunities, but the Grand Canyon is spiritually and culturally significant for indigenous people. It is estimated that humans have lived in and around the Grand Canyon for about 10,000 years with the Ancestral Puebloan People (sometimes called Anasazi) arriving around 200 B.C.E. The Ancestral Pueblo carved in the limestone near the foot of the Nankoweap Trail, and these are examples of ancient seed- and food-storage facilities that can still be seen there. Although the details of what happened are not well understood, the Ancestral Pueblo civilization collapsed around A.D. 1110. After this, other Native American tribes moved into the canyon. They began migrating between the inner canyon and the upper plateau. Until the mid-1800s eleven tribes called the Grand Canyon home but were forced out as settlers moved west<sup>2</sup>.

1Grand Canyon National Park. (2023). Geology.National Park Service.
https://www.nps.gov/grca/learn/nature/grca-geology.htm

2Terrill, M. (2019). Native American view of the Grand Canyon's centennial celebration.
Arizona State University.
https://news.asu.edu/20190211-discoveries-how-native-americans-view-grand-canyons-centennial-celebration

pageData.desc: Nankoweap Granaries of the Grand Canyon. Rooms with rectangular entrances carved into the side of the canyon.
pageData.altText: Nankoweap Granaries of the Grand Canyon. Rooms with rectangular entrances carved into the side of the canyon.

pageData.text: The phrase “What goes up must come down” is a good way to sum up the natural hazard of . Mass wasting, also known as mass movement, generally refers to gravity forcing materials such as rocks and soil in a downward slope motion. Mass wasting usually occurs after weathering and erosion and can play a major role in landform formation. As rocks erode and break down they become less stable. When these rocks are under gravitational stress they become subject to mass wasting. Debris from this process are often deposited into streams or other flowing bodies of water. The streams carrying the fallen debris can modify and chisel the earth’s surface into various landforms. There are different types of mass wasting and different characteristics a scientist would use to classify them. This includes the type of rock, the speed of the material as it moves downward, and how much water is in the material. Despite the role mass wasting has on the natural landscape, in the United States, mass wasting damages can cost over a billion dollars and lead to many deaths a year. The Appalachian and Rocky Mountains along with Alaska and Hawaii experience mass wasting issues more frequently than other areas.

pageData.subTitle: Causes of Mass Wasting
pageData.text: Oversteepened slopes are a major trigger for . Oversteepened slopes can be caused by natural occurrences (i.e. flowing water around the base) as well as anthropogenic causes (i.e. deforestation). The steepest angle where rock and (the layer of loosely arranged sediment covering bedrock) are at rest is known as the . Angles of repose can range from 33˚ to 37˚; however, an oversteepened slope can have an angle range of 40˚ to 60˚ (this can vary based on the amount of water in the material and grain size and texture). most likely occur when the angle is 40˚ to 60˚, at which point the gravitational force has won. The landslide shown in Figure 1 occurred in La Conchita, a southern California coastal environment in 1995. This event resulted in evacuation, and homes near the were lost. Water plays a significant role in mass wasting events. Dry particles will prey to gravity faster than wet particles because they only rely on friction to keep them bound. Building a sand castle with dry sand is very hard compared to using damp sand. The damp sand exhibits cohesion between its particles and these particles tend to stick together more readily. Too much water can also be troublesome. Excessive rainfall (water) will cause a break down in the cohesion and therefore can lead to landslides. On a microscopic level, water saturation is noted because the water inhabiting spaces between the particles cause the pieces to move farther and farther apart, reducing friction. Think of the damp sand and how easy it is to make the sandcastle. If you added more water to the sand it would become harder for the castle to maintain its form.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Aerial photo showing a rotational landslide (slump) that occurred in La Conchita, a southern California coastal community, in 1995. Houses are shown at the bottom of the photo, and a large bluff looms directly above, which is covered in avocado and citrus orchards, which sit atop poorly cemented marine sediment.

pageData.text: Photo courtesy U.S. Geological Survey

Deforestation, or the general removal of vegetation, can trigger . The roots of plants unite to form a complex web between the and the soil. This stability protects against erosion and mass wasting. In areas where the slope is steep and there is excessive rainfall, a loss of vegetation will more than likely result in a mass wasting occurrence.

Another notable yet rare trigger of mass wasting are earthquakes. Conditions suitable for a mass wasting event can be present without any fallen debris for many years. However, the tremors and seismic waves produced by earthquakes can dislodge and dismantle rock, leading to <button class='glossary-text'>landslides</button> in a matter of seconds. Weak slopes will fail under the energy and stress from plate movement. Oftentimes earthquakes, landslides, and the lowering of the earth’s surface (land subsidence) can be the cause of the worst damage cities usually experience.

When geologists are not present to see the mass wasting occur, they can observe the anatomy of the landslide. By looking at the , geologists can determine if the landslide recently happened. Head scarp is characterized by a steep area that exposes soil and rock. This is the location where the rock and regolith broke away. Scars on the side of the mountain reveal lighter-colored, younger rocks. At the bottom of the landslide, , or the older fallen rock, would be present.

pageData.subTitle: Kinds of Motion
pageData.text: It is easy to refer to all events of mass wasting as landslides. However other events are possible based on certain factors. Depending on the type of material (rock, mud, <button class='glossary-text'>pyroclastic</button> material, etc.) and the location, mass wasting may occur fast or slow, and can cause major problems or minor issues. Scientists classify the mass wasting based on these factors. In Figure 2, the major groups are represented with examples of mass wasting events.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram listing the 10 major groups of mass wasting events, with examples of each: A) Rotational landslide; B) Translational landslide; C) Block slide; D) Rockfall; E) Topple; F) Debris Flow; G) Debris avalanche; H) Earthflow; I) Creep; and J) Lateral Spread.

pageData.question: Rocks under what type of stress can become subject to mass wasting?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As rocks erode and break down, they become less stable. When these rocks are under gravitational stress, they become subject to mass wasting.

pageData.question: How can deforestation trigger mass wasting?

options.text: Deforestation takes away plant roots, reducing soil stability.
Deforestation equipment compacts the soil, making it denser.
Deforestation dries out the soil, reducing the cohesion between soil particles.
Deforestation changes the slope angle, making it more susceptible to gravity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Deforestation removes vegetation, and this can trigger mass wasting. The roots of plants unite to form a complex web between the regolith and the soil. This stability protects against erosion and mass wasting.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Mass wasting, also known as mass movement, generally refers to gravity forcing materials such as rocks and soil in a downward slope motion. Water plays a significant role in mass wasting events. Dry particles will fall prey to gravity faster than wet particles because they only rely on friction to keep them bound. Building a sandcastle with dry sand is very hard compared to using damp sand. The damp sand exhibits cohesion between its particles and these particles tend to stick together more readily. Too much water can also be troublesome. Excessive rainfall will cause a breakdown in the cohesion and therefore can lead to landslides. Vegetation, or its removal, is also significant to mass wasting. The roots of plants form a complex web between the regolith and the soil, which stability protects against erosion and mass wasting. A notable, yet rare, trigger of mass wasting is earthquakes. Tremors and seismic waves produced by earthquakes can dislodge and dismantle rock, leading to landslides.

Water plays a significant role in mass wasting events. Dry particles will fall prey to gravity faster than wet particles because they only rely on friction to keep them bound. Building a sandcastle with dry sand is very hard compared to using damp sand. The damp sand exhibits cohesion between its particles and these particles tend to stick together more readily. Too much water can also be troublesome. Excessive rainfall will cause a breakdown in the cohesion and therefore can lead to landslides. Vegetation, or its removal, is also significant to mass wasting. The roots of plants form a complex web between the regolith and the soil, which stability protects against erosion and mass wasting. A notable, yet rare, trigger of mass wasting is earthquakes. Tremors and seismic waves produced by earthquakes can dislodge and dismantle rock, leading to landslides.

img.alt: Figure 2: Diagram listing the 10 major groups of mass wasting events, with examples of each: A) Rotational landslide; B) Translational landslide; C) Block slide; D) Rockfall; E) Topple; F) Debris Flow; G) Debris avalanche; H) Earthflow; I) Creep; and J) Lateral Spread.

pageData.text: When rock and pieces freely down the slope it is known as a fall. occur as rocks rotate forward sometimes because of adjacent rocks shifting or repeated freeze-thaw cycles creating cracks and breaks. Material can move along the surface without breaking into many smaller pieces; this is called a . On the other hand, material can move as a slurry of debris, rock, and regolith, which viscous fluid scientists have dubbed as .

<button class='glossary-text'>Rock avalanches</button> are one of the fastest <button class='glossary-text'>mass wasting</button> events. Debris can travel over 100 miles per hour during these events. Air is trapped underneath the falling rock and appears to float down the surface as a large, flexible sheet.

In contrast to the faster moving rock avalanches, <button class='glossary-text'>creeps</button> usually occur slowly over time and can be found in colder climates. During freeze-thaw cycles, particles expand when frozen and fall back down when thawed out. Due to the slow nature of movement creeps have, the changes occurring are not visible as they are occurring. However, over longer periods of time, the change in the surface is more apparent. Trees, fences and houses will begin to lean on the incline. <button class='glossary-text'>Solifluction</button> is a type of creep that can be found in the tundra regions because the permafrost inhibits the water to be absorbed and results in the active layer (layer above the permafrost) to become saturated.

A <button class='glossary-text'>slump</button>, or rotational <button class='glossary-text'>landslide</button>, refers to a slower moving, organized chunk of rock or regolith that moves along a curved surface. Slumps do not travel far and are usually found in areas rich in clays. Overly-steepened slopes are a major cause of slumps and are a common type of mass wasting.

<button class='glossary-text'>Rockslides</button> are comprised of only rock (usually bedrock) and move extremely fast. In fact, rockslides can be one of the more destructive types of mass wasting. <button class='glossary-text'>Debris flow</button> is similar to a rockslide but only consists of regolith and/or soil. Generally, debris flow has a high water content. Larger rocks and boulders can be found in the debris flow. <button class='glossary-text'>Mudflows</button> are mainly comprised of mud but could also carry smaller rocks and occasionally boulders. The speed of debris flow and mudflow is dependent on the water content and slope angle. An increase in water content or increase in slope would lead to a faster moving flow.

<button class='glossary-text'>Lahars</button> are <button class='glossary-text'>mudflows</button> that occur when the <button class='glossary-text'>pyroclastic</button> material from a volcano enters a body of water that surrounds the base of the volcano. Volcanic ash mixes with water or forms of precipitation (such as rain or snow) and make up the lahar. Due to the fluidity of the lahar it can be hard to predict its path and can easily take out anything in its way. Lahar can have a maximum temperature of 100˚ C. When Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980, the state of Washington suffered severely. A debris avalanche swept away highways, bridges, roads and buildings (Figure 3). This event was noted as the largest <button class='glossary-text'>landslide</button> incident in history. An evacuation plan saved many people despite how fast the lahars were moving, and only 5–10 people were reported dead. When the Nevada del Ruiz volcano erupted in 1985, the nearby town of Amero was covered in lahar. This small city in the country of Colombia lost 20,000 of its 25,000 residents.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Black and white photo showing the Mount St. Helens eruption of 1980. The volcano is shown erupting in the background, with ash billowing from the crater. In the foreground, lahar is seen flowing down the base of the volcano.

pageData.text: Photo courtesy U.S. Geological Survey

pageData.question: Which of these is NOT a type of mass wasting motion?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Strike-slip is a type of fault, not a mass wasting event.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between a lahar and a mudflow?

options.text: Lahars are comprised of volcanic ash and water rather than mud.
Lahars are mudflows down the slopes of volcanoes rather than the slopes of mountains.
Lahars are mudflows at temperatures greater than 100° C.
Lahars are mudflows at temperatures less than 100° C.
Lahars contain mud as well as rocks rather than mud only.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Lahars are mudflows formed when volcanic ash mixes with water or other forms of precipitation.

Mudflows are mainly comprised of mud but can also carry smaller rocks and occasionally boulders. The speed of debris flow and mudflow is dependent on the water content and slope angle. An increase in water content or increase in slope would lead to a faster moving flow. Lahars are mudflows that occur when the pyroclastic material from a volcano enters a body of water that surrounds the base of the volcano. Volcanic ash mixes with water or forms of precipitation (such as rain or snow) and make up the lahar.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning, you will download Google Earth Pro. In Activity 1, you will open Google Earth Pro and enter the specified location. Then, you will observe the location before the mass wasting event occurred and take a screenshot. Next, you will observe the location after the mass wasting event occurred and take a screenshot. Then, you will compare the before and after images and describe the evidence of mast wasting. Next, you will calculate the area of the mass wasting event. Then, you will record the height of the terrain before and after the mass wasting event. Finally, you will repeat this for a total of 3 locations.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the steepest angle at which rock and regolith are at rest?
On average, how many deaths per year do mass wasting events cause?
Landslides are most likely to occur on a slope with what steepness?
Which of the following is NOT a cause of mass wasting?
Which of the following is the location where rock and regolith broke away during a mass wasting event?
What type of mass wasting event occurs when material moves along the surface without breaking into many smaller pieces?
During which of these mass wasting events can debris travel over 100 miles per hour?
Which of these mass wasting events is slow-moving?

options.text: debris flow with an increase in water content
mudflow with an increase in slope

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Download Google Earth Pro*
*Google Earth Pro, Google,https://www.google.com/earth/about/
Accept the agreement and download. You can open Google Earth Pro from the desktop after installation.

In Activity 1, you will use <button class='resource-text'>Google Earth Pro</button> to examine various locations before and after <button class='glossary-text'>mass wasting</button> events, compare the height of the terrain before and after the events, and calculate the area of the mass wasting event.

typeBefore.text: In this lab you will evaluate a landscape and the <button class='glossary-text'>mass wasting</button> processes that have occurred using <button class='resource-text'>Google Earth Pro</button>. You then explore different locations of your choice. You will determine if they have experienced mass wasting in the past and predict if they are vulnerable to mass wasting in the future.

pageData.text: Once you have opened the program, you will notice a search bar in your upper left-hand corner. Enter the location at the coordinates for latitude and longitude: 18° 21' 6" N, 72° 52' 14.0" W (Port-au-Prince, Republic of Haiti).

Google Earth Pro has the feature available to look at historical data. At the top of the page, you will find a toolbar that contains multiple buttons. Click the one that has a clock with a green arrow. In the upper left hand corner of the image field you will notice a sliding bar that can be adjusted to change the date. Change the year to 2010 (pull the bar all the way back to the left).
Click the Save button at the top of the image field in the toolbar (second button from the end on the right).

<button class='glossary-text'>Landslides</button> are common after earthquakes. An earthquake occurred in Port-au-Prince, Republic of Haiti on January 12, 2010. Now <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button> the bar to a year before 2010. Notice the loss of vegetation associated with mass wasting. Click the Save button at the top of the image field in the toolbar.
Compare the two images that you saved. What are some other noticeable differences between the images that would be indicative of mass wasting? Record your observations in Data Table 1.
Compare the images again and make note of evidence of landslides, rock , etc. Record your observations in Data Table 1.

Now, identify landslides using the toolbar (icon looks like a hexagon and a plus sign) at the top to draw a polygon around the landslide to calculate the area the landslide covered. Do this by comparing the time periods in Google Earth Pro, not on the captured image. Click on points at the perimeter of the slide until the slide is covered by the shape you create. Record the area of slide in square meters (m2) in Data Table 1.

You can also look at the elevation to determine if the ground has been leveled, in Google Earth Pro. Place the cursor over the landform and view the toolbar at the bottom that shows the imagery date, latitude and longitude, elevation, and eye altitude. Note: you may need to close the Tour Guide bar by clicking on the words “tour guide” to see this toolbar. Compare and contrast the elevations of the various landforms and mass wasting and record the height of each terrain (before and after) in Data Table 1.

Now, you will chose two different locations and determine what mass wasting events may have occurred or may occur in the future. To do this, first brainstorm a list of potential sites to explore. You may consider locations near your home or places you have recently visited that have topography which may put them at risk for mass wasting or locations that have been in the news for natural disasters such as earthquakes, fires, volcanic eruptions or floods. In addition, consider areas that are prone to heavy rainfall and steep topography. For example, in the U.S, California and the Pacific Northwest have been known to experience mass wasting events on large scales. If you would like to see mass events that have occurred world-wide, here is a link to Catastrophic Landslides of the 20th Century - Worldwide | U.S. Geological Survey.

For each location you have chosen, record the site coordinates, location name, observations and evidence of mass wasting event, area of slide, and height of the terrain before and after the event. Record your data in Data Table 2.

For each location, take a screen shot of the area before and after the mass wasting event that you identified.  Zooming in and out of the area will help you identify more specific details. Just make sure that the images are in the same parameters when you save them so that you compare the same images.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

data.title: Angle of repose
data.content: The steepest angle where rock and regolith are at rest on a slope

data.title: Creep
data.content: A slow downslope movement of debris

data.title: Debris flow
data.content: A flow of material that consists of regolith and/or soil

data.title: Fall
data.content: Rock and regolith pieces that fall freely down a slope

data.title: Flow
data.content: When material that moves as a slurry of debris, rock and regolith which has a viscous flow

data.title: Head scarp
data.content: A steep area that exposes soil and rock resulting from rock and regolith breaking away

data.title: Lahar
data.content: A mudflow that occurs when pyroclastic material from a volcano enters a body of water

data.title: Landslide
data.content: The sliding down of a mass of earth or rock from a mountain or cliff

data.title: Mass wasting
data.content: A geologic event that is the result of gravity forcing materials such as rocks and soil in a downward slope motion; also known as mass movement

data.title: Mudflow
data.content: A flow of material that consists mostly of mud and smaller rocks and boulders

data.title: Pyroclastic
data.content: Consisting of fragments of rock erupted by a volcano

data.title: Regolith
data.content: A region of loose, unconsolidated rock and dust that sits atop a layer of bedrock

data.title: Rock avalanche
data.content: A sudden rock flow that can reach over 100 mph

data.title: Rockslide
data.content: A slide comprised of only rock that moves extremely fast

data.title: Slide
data.content: When material moves down a slope without breaking into smaller pieces

data.title: Slump
data.content: The downward movement of a block of earth along a curved surface

data.title: Solifluction
data.content: A type of creep that can be found in the tundra regions because the permafrost inhibits water to be absorbed  and results in the layer above the permafrost to become saturated

data.title: Talus
data.content: Older, fallen rock that can be found at the base of a landslide

data.title: Topple
data.content: The forward rotation of rocks or slabs
